author: potuz
content: I have a different theory: I think someone high up in the Ethereum community is behind ETHW. All this weirdness is great for Ethereum, it doesn't make sense if you want to fork ETH that they'll **continue** mining past the merge without changing chainid and they'll only do so after a while. I think this is only done so that the merge gets enough hashrate ðŸ˜„

author: nxs9986
content:
Sorry if this is wrong place to ask, but I have a tracing mystery for this tx :

https://goerli.etherscan.io/tx/0x08d3efbbd3d388b132c42b0030cf10ee95ebdd1632439e21dc1acb97c16462f4

The tx fee was 115932000115932 wei with 115931998956612 tip for miner, but the trace shows a state change of 149004998658955 wei for the miner, more than it actually received. https://goerli.etherscan.io/tx/0x08d3efbbd3d388b132c42b0030cf10ee95ebdd1632439e21dc1acb97c16462f4#statechange

The difference is 33â€¯072â€¯999â€¯702â€¯343 wei .... how much the miner would received if the tx used the entire gas limit 149,005, but it actually used 115,932 

It would appear the trace is actually 'wrong' since it shows miner receiving more than it actually did. Does anyone know whats going on here?

author: lapdo
content: Hey everyone, I have recently started writing my MSc thesis on the Quantum Threat and Ethereum, but currently i am still writing my research proposal. I will be analysing the current cryptography methods that are used in Eth and see how one would be able to make the network quantum-safe by integrating the appropriate post-quantum cryptography methods (e.g. the four finalists announced by NIST and potential other ones that are relevant). After this, i will look at technological barriers for implementation (compatibility, trade-offs etc.), while also looking into organisational obstacles (soft/hard fork). Is there anyone in here that can give me some advice/guidance on this particular topic. Thank you very much!!
